Situation1: Communicate openly to resolve conflicts or misunderstandings.
Situation2: They see a group of teenagers ignoring the no-diving signs near the pool edge.
Story: I stood at the edge of the pool, whistle in hand, scanning the water for any signs of trouble. My little sister, Mia, was among a group of teenagers clustered near the deep end, laughter echoing off the tiles. Suddenly, I saw her climb onto the pool edge, egged on by her friends, ignoring the bold red “No Diving” sign. My heart clenched. As a lifeguard, I was expected to enforce the rules, no exceptions, to keep everyone safe. But as her sister, I knew Mia hated being called out in front of her friends—she’d see it as a betrayal, another reason to accuse me of acting superior. I could already imagine her glare, the cold shoulder later, the accusations that I never take her side. But if I let it slide, I’d be failing my duty, risking her safety and my job. The whistle felt heavy in my hand as I wrestled with what to do, torn between the responsibility to protect and the hope of building trust with my sister.
